segments.text: Okay, so this general?
So this general, General Vogel, who was commanding at Camp at the San Diego area, was going to go to Parris Island.
He said, do I want to go along?
I said, no, I can't go that far back.
There ain't no war at Parris Island.
I'm going to stick here.
So it wasn't 24 hours that I was ordered to sing back.
assigned to the staff of the commanding officer of Pacific Fleet Sing Pack.
And was that in Hawaii?
In Hawaii.
So then I was assigned to the... Let me get my own pen for this shit.
Maybe it'll make a note for you.
All right.
And I organized a battalion there in Pearl Harbor and participated in the assault on Guam.
Now... Tell me about that.
Well, I just had a battalion in the assault on Guam.
That was it.
And when it was secured, then we got to be the island command.
See?
And my command, that same general there ran the whole island.
During the assault, you commanded a battalion.
The battalion went ashore.
Yeah, it went ashore, but it was a headquartered battalion.
We just had outpost skirmishes around.
So you weren't on the frontal assault?
Yes, we were.
Not the frontal assault, no.
As soon as they secured the beachhead, then you went ashore?
No, we hadn't been secured yet.
They were still fighting when I went ashore.
Did that one say Guam?
Wait a minute.
All right.
I'll just read you the part you want to hear.
Okay, fine.

Colonel Baraka landed with the assault units in initial landing with Guam, with 5th Corps, and continued in that status until the enemy, until the enemy and mortar and artillery fire at Agate landing area at our first command post in the vicinity of Delvin.
Carrying out military assignments, he came under heavy sniper fire on the 25th of July, 1944, and he was on duty reconnoitering the location for a forward command post
which duty he performed on the intense enemy sniper and small-arm fire.
Again, at PD about this same period, Colonel Baraka was on the enemy sniper fire from the Japanese forces who had been bypassed by our troops or who had infiltrated into our position.
Establishing our CP at the base of Mount Tenya, Colonel Baraka and his unit came on the enemy grenade and fire
when he commanded his fifth caliber machine gun crew and wiped out the enemy detachment.
That was my combat.
You got it all?
They did get it?
Sure.
All right.
That was it.
When they give you these citations, they don't lie, see?
But that citation, that's how they had them.
advanced me to Brigadier on the retired list.
Oh, it did?
Sure.
It says so there.
So that was one of the main reasons for Brigadier, for your promotion.
Oh, hell, I was going to be made Brigadier, maybe.
I was number five, number seven on the list of colonels.
I could have made it, but you know what I mean.
I'm not a politician.
I knew I had that record, and I knew what the law was.
When I had to retire, I knew they had to promote me.
I didn't have a bad record.
If I'd had a bad record, I wouldn't have done anything.
All right, now we're coming from that.
Now we're on Guam.
Now, here's something I don't like to write about.
In the middle of one morning, along about 4 o'clock, I was relieved of my battalion to quell a riot, which was supposed to have happened.
in the city of a canyon where, at some prior time, some seabee had killed one of the black Navy troops over that, over the embarkation area.
It was a black and tan outfit where they unloaded ships on, oh hell, I can't call the name.
Landing ships?
Transports?
No, no, no, no, no.
It's a hollow big piece of metal.
You link them together.
Christ, I can't.
I'm too old.
Anyhow, when you can't get up on the beach to unload your ships, you put these things together.
They're made out of iron.
Sure, they're like runways.
Oh, what the hell you call them?
I can't think of the word.
Anyhow, this outfit was from there.
They were Seabees.
Huh?
They were Seabees?
No, they weren't Seabees.
They were Navy.
They were Navy.
But the Seabees were also on the island.
And were all the navies, were all they black or were they integrated or what?
Oh, the navy wasn't integrated fully yet.
Anyhow, some of these people got over on this island who had been in the same outfit over on Siopan that had killed a navy nurse and raped her dead body.
And killed a lieutenant in the navy who went there to retrieve her body.
Some of these people came from that outfit.
Some of the Seabees did?
Some of these Navy people did.
So they decided to come in on a Ganya and gonna shoot up a Ganya because one of these Seabees, one night in a thatched hut, was gonna come in and visit.
And the Seabee said, told him he wasn't invited there.
About that time this Navy
Black Navy man threw a keyboard knife at him and about that time the CB reached in the top of his thatch hut and filled him with his carbine filled him with a hole.
I knew nothing about that because that happened while I'm still a battalion commander.
But anyhow, the Provo Marshal at the time was drunk.
My commanding officer was very impatient, so he was looking for his old pro marshal from back in Samoa, and his attorney generally trusted hands, so I had the job.
So I rushed down into a canyon and got ahold of one platoon of the military police, and we flanked these people.
The trucks came in there, 20 trucks, and they were loaded.
They had hand grenades, they had tear gas, they had automatics and everything, and we flanked them with
Tommy guns, and we didn't, we had 200 of them, and we didn't have to fire a shot.
So then we put these people into a stockade, and later on they would try to riot and rock, and Mrs. Roseville turned them all loose.
And at that hearing, a fellow named White, who was the head man of the National Association of Advanced Recovered People, asked to be counseled for the accused on the Board of Investigations.
It was granted to him.
And of course, as I say, they were all convicted.
But when they got back to the United States, they were turned loose.
Convicted of rioting?
They were all convicted of rioting?
Yeah, riot and rioting.
Was there a lot of racial tension?
Or was this the only incident?
Only certain incidents.
When the committee came down from Washington to ask me about it,
about whether there was any racial segregation and so forth and so on like that.
I said, I didn't intimidate.
I said, I didn't know.
I haven't seen any of it.
Well, they said, here you got a boatswain killed at a canteen for Black Navy people and Black Army people.
I said, what did you do about this boatswain killing this man?
I says, I read the report and I freed him.
Why?
I says, upon investigation, I found out that this was a black Red Cross woman.
He was worried when he was warned to leave her alone and leave her alone.
And when he went to put him under arrest, this black woman said she didn't come down there to be a whore.
She came down there to be a Red Cross woman.
And, uh...
He broke arrest, and he fired on him.
And I says, then again, at the foot of Mount Tanyar, some of these people held up this bus taking this woman to the Red Cross compound.
And another Black Navy boatman who was in charge, he fired on him.
Kill him?
I don't know.
There's no report of being killed.
So then you say there's no... That's not the word.
Not integration.
I don't know when you feel...
Prejudice?
Prejudice.
That's the word.
I don't know.
I don't know prejudice.
I know anything about it.
So in that committee, there was a two-and-a-half-striped black man, and there was this great football player by the name of Pollard, and there was also another black congressman
And I understand later on...
They all came out from Washington, D.C.?
That's right, to investigate...
This incident?
Yeah.
No, just in general.
Oh, in general.
Oh, okay.
Yeah, in general.
Okay.
So I understand they went up and told that flag secretary, that Admiral Nimitz's staff, that redneck down there.
Called me a redneck.
Said they didn't get much satisfaction out of him.
Out of you.
That's right.
All right.
Now...
But did you think of yourself as a redneck?
Huh?
Did you agree with them, what they said?
Well, sure.
I didn't give them too much information.
I told them the truth.
I could back up everything I told them with my record.
I had 47 people in my headquarters as a Provo Marshal.
It wasn't no bullshit outfit.
Here's a picture of it.
I called it Leary Junction.
The Admiral was named Leary.
at this road.
He was taking a prisoner, and this is my headquarters in, what's the name, out of that we ran five stockades of Japanese.
We had 30,000 Japanese prisoners on there.
I had the Navy, I had the Navy brig, and I had the Marine Corps brig, and I had all the stockades of Japanese.
That was all part of the job as Provo Marshal, plus policing the roads.
Policing the docks.
I had control of the rodents.
I had to see if they had rat guards when the ship landed.
To keep the rats coming, because we had a program of rodents on the beach.
That was all.
The roads.
The building of roads with asphalt.
The moving of asphalt.
The moving of ammunition.
The moving of troops.
The moving of...
The native personnel, that all came under the Provo Marshal.
Okay, so you were in charge of all of those things?
That's right.
So in order to do that, I had, as I say here, I had one regiment of military policemen.
Luckily, I trained one battalion back in Pearl Harbor.
That was one of them out of Nucleus.
But they only had rifle specs.
They were not schooled as military police.
We had to school them.
Then I had two battalions of army from Fort...
Acosta, Wyoming.
They were good.
They were better than the Marines.
They did all my narcotic work.
And they did all that because that time a lot of dope was coming in from China and places like that.
Really?
That's right.
Did you have a drug problem on the island?
But these people stopped the drug problem.
What kind of drugs?
I guess cocaine, morphine, stuff they use up in China.
And these people came in and stopped the drug problems?
They assisted in it.
There's a... Shit, we could talk here two years about this damn thing.
That's why I was putting things on the road there as the... Every time we get a Marine killed, you see, we put one of them signs up to try to keep him from...
There's a pro, there he is, there's a son of a bitch.
Here's when I had the battalion, Margaret Chase came down from Maine.
Really?
Into my command post, and the shooting hadn't stopped yet.
No kidding?
That's right.
That's who she is.
Senator.
There's the old Olympia, was in the Spanish-American War, which came down there as a tender carrying ammunition.
There's a flight mess when we were bringing back some wounded.
There's raising the flag on Guam.
There's my army liaison in my headquarters.
How many of your officers on your staff are lawyers?
Three of them.
And how many officers on your staff?
And how many men in your command?
Well, my command, my command was this regimental military policeman and the two battalions of army.
Okay.
There's the old goat right there.
Mm-hmm.
We'd take some Japanese Britain and I wouldn't.
We got these off a submarine.
Mm-hmm.
I said, Jesus Christ, I got more damn material here.
But tell me about your prisoners.
All right, we're going to finish now.
Tell me about the Japanese prisoners.
Okay.
We took the Japanese, you know, when we landed there, we
They were all mixed up with Chemorins.
The island of Saipan is just across, and it's the same nationality.
And these people have been going back and forth through the years.
After the assault was over, it was my job to get those civilians out of there.
That is, we let them stay there until they were all filtered out.
Well, in order to do that, we had to have the G2 people take care of that.
We had people, Marines could speak Japanese.
Incidentally, they had a school back in Samoa that taught Japanese and English.
I can tell you a lot of stuff, but anyhow.
So, we had these different stockades.
And as they'd bring these prisoners in, of course,
They'd interrogate them and so forth for the G2 people so they'd get the word out to the people in the field how many more Japs there was.
Remember, we got to show you, we were getting in Japs there even after I left Guam, many years after that.
Anyhow, I had no trouble with the Japanese prisoners themselves.
because I had to have one stockade for Japanese officers.
They didn't want to work.
If you worked, I'd give you 1,200 calories of food a day.
If you didn't, I'd lessen the calories down.
We formed these people out each day to different divisions.
The third division, the brigades, the army,
and the Navy and any all the troops who were stationed on the island.
We'd portion out a certain many of Japanese prisoners.
They'd take and work them and feed them on their own command and bring them back in in the evenings.
Were they pretty good workers?
We all had to work them.
Sure they were good workers.
They all worked.
But one time we had a very thing happen.
We had a whole medical battalion from Iwo of Japanese and
Some naval doctors thought it would be a good idea for the people to have these Japanese doctors look after the Japanese.
So I agreed to all that.
The first thing you know, 90% of the Japanese are on sick report.
so they wouldn't have to wait.
So I changed that.
I put a sick call at 3 o'clock in the morning and immediately there was no more problems.
Because everybody depended on the Japanese.
Back in the back area, you take a division that's been up in combat, come back to the back area to rest.
There was a lot of work the police and these Japs could do, and they did it.
And we let the Red Cross use them.
I let them use them until I went by there one day and made an inspection.
They had them sitting down there and tea with them, which was against the rules.
So no more, they didn't get any more prisoners.
But the 20th Air Force got them, the B-29 field got them, and we got them all.
So they do manual labor?
Yeah, yeah.
Then we had two trucks going around the island picking up cans and things like that because Admiral Nimitz wanted the island cleaned up.
I'll give you, I think I, man, I don't know.
Was there a lot of hatred?
A lot of what?
Hatred?
No.
I only had one trouble one time.
I didn't have any trouble.
I was allowed under the Articles of War just so much.
Well, I had all those prisoners, and it was impossible to give them, give each one of them a pair of shoes or give them this and this and the other.
So what I did, I saved the shoes for the Marines and just cut a piece of wood
They made sandals out of wood and a string, and that was it.
They were useless, and everybody was happy.

But everything went along all right until I ran into a psychological warfare officer from the University of Chicago, a two-and-a-half strapper, and he complained about this incident, because I'm about to tell you.
My commanding general told me to carry out the Articles of War as far as it was practical.
He also told me to use my own judgment in any matters that arise.
The article of war says you don't parade the prisoners after dark.
I got a signal from the G2 staff FMF pack that all the G2s of the six divisions were coming in to Guam and wanted to check the stockade.
It was way after dark when the lieutenant called me, and I ordered him to parade the prisoners.

There was one officer, the head of the prison, named by Colonel Mac Pate, who later got to be commandant of the Marine Corps, whose father was a classmate of one of these naval officers, a Navy captain, who was taken prisoner and whipped that ass down to Guam naked.
Anyhow, he had been repatriated, and he wrote back.
So this officer went in there, this Colonel Pate, who was the head of this G-2 team, and it was after dark.
And I asked him, he says, did you ever think that a lot of us like to cut your down throat?
And he bowed.
And he says, he called for a certain Jap by the name of Shimizu.
So the sergeant said, Shimizu, front and center.
And what do you do?
He said, I'm the baker.
Shimizu was commissioned by the emperor who had set up all this hatred between the Gormanians, the Chemurans, and also the Chemurans from Saipan.
He had free run there, but his name was Shimizu.
So he said, did you ever stop things like cut your throat?
So this Japanese says, yes, I did, and he bowed.
Well, they asked a lot of other questions, and I had some Gonzukas.
The Gonzukas were Korean prisoners from the Japanese.
It was Japanese that made them work, and they called them Gonzukas.
So we had some of them lined up there, and we had tags on them.
So Colonel Payton asked me, he says, what does that mean?
I said, well, he's a metalsmith.
He's a this, he's a that, he's the other.
So...
So I said, and the pigs, they age.
So they went and asked questions here, there, and everywhere.
And then they finally went up on the hill and said, what are those two little chick sails you got up there?
I said, those I got two guys eating one of the cannibals.
I says, uh, well, he said, we'd like to go up there.
I said, for what?
He said, well, I saw the entourage.
I went on up there with them.
And, uh, one of these naval officers, a naval officer was there, off Admiral Limited's staff.
He wanted to see what they looked like.
So he tapped on there, and the sergeant says, he's indisposed right now.
So he wanted to know why he was indisposed.
He says, well, he's taking, moving his bowels in a bucket.
Anyhow, after that, we brought him out and looked at him anyhow, and started another one over there on the hill.
Well, why can't you keep them with the other Japs?
I said, well, that's the only hatred in here.
I said, well, I put that Jap loose down here, he'll be dead in five minutes.
So anyhow...
The people of Guam hated him.
Huh?
So the people of Guam... Yeah, they'd beat the hell out of them.
They'd beat them and raped them and everything else while they were there.
So the people of Guam hated him.
Oh, yeah, they were really mean to him.
Anyhow, the...

So the next day, I get a report from my commanding general to come see him, and I got my jeep and I went up to see what it was all about, and he asked me, he said, you did your parade to prisoners last night.
I said, I did, sir.
He says, anything happen?
I said, nothing that unusual.
He says, well, this...
psychological warfare officer from the University of Chicago up there on Nimitz and Stamp read in hell about that that you permitted a lot of unusual things to happen in that stockade last night.
And a lot of things went on.
A lot of people said things.
I said, sir, if there were anything on the other line, I never heard it.
If I'd have said what Pete said, Pete never would have been accommodating Marine Corps.
But anyhow,

So he picked up the telephone and called them into the headquarters in my presence and said, this island is not big enough for that psychological warfare guy you got up there, and I want him off this island by noon today.
Those are orders.
And he was gone.
That's General Lawson.
His father-in-law was governor of Colorado, and his brother-in-law was governor of Colorado.
All right, we're down to...
But tell me one last thing before we leave the Japanese.
Well, hell, I got a picture to show you.
It'll come out of your ass.
Well, tell me, how did the Americans treat the prisoners?
Well, they were not contact.
We didn't have them around them.
Only time when they went up in working parties.
They didn't shoot.
They...
You know, the Japanese treated the American prisoners really poorly.
Oh, of course they did.
I was wondering if we treated the Japanese prisoners real poorly.
Oh, no.
Uh-uh.
No.
Why not?
Because it wasn't the right thing to do.
It wasn't the right thing to do.
Why, uh...
I'll give you this picture.
That is Lieutenant Colonel.
What year was this?
It's on the list there.
Self-explanatory.
Put it on the back there, Tent 12.
And I found it.
And I gave you a picture.
And later on, you'll get a picture of me as a general.
Of course, you can go up there and look at it up there.
What year was this?
This is 1914, probably?
What?
Let's see, what'd I say I was looking for?
Pictures of Japanese prisoners.
Orders and requests.
Charge reports.
Brutality, the Chinese against the Japanese.
Yeah.
Photos of the Japanese army in China during the
Signed on Japanese war in 1937.
Oh yeah, this is incredible.
These pictures are too horrible for publication.

If you wish to reproduce these pictures or use them for propaganda purposes in the division, they should prove very useful in rousing the wrath of any right-minded young American against such barbaric actions.
However, I would prefer not to have
my name associated with them in any way.
When you have made whatever slides or copies you may need for your purposes, please give back the originals to Mrs. Price.
Charles F.B.
Price.
He was my general.
He was your general?
Of the Samoan Defense Force after General Austin left.
There's some of the pictures we had, but we did get these pictures and get them out to the troops.
You understand that?
Oh, you did.
You're damn right we did.
to show the brutality of the Japanese.
I don't think you want that, maybe you do, maybe you don't.
These are incredible.
If you want them, you can take them and reproduce them and send them back.
Maybe you don't want them.
But those are all the things I had to do.
Yeah.
Give me that, put that down.
Those are all the things they charged me with.
You understand?
Sure.
G2 people and all like that.
If I say you could sit in and talk, you'd say, well, you could just be blowing smoke up your ass.
It's been passed.
You're 87 and a half years old.
You're ready to meet the maker.
What the hell are you?
You know?
That's the brutality of the Japanese.
And so you'd give those pictures... We had them produced and passed around into divisions.
And another reason why...

The Marines didn't want to have taken Jap prisoners because in Guadalcanal, when we made a reconnaissance in force, I wasn't there, but Frank Getchie, who was a great football player, he was in charge of this reconnaissance in force.
And they underestimated the amount of resistance they'd get.
And 22 of those people were wiped out, or maybe 40.
And when the Marines went there to find him, the Japanese had cut the penises off of every Marine and stuck it in his mouth.
And after the Marines knew that and heard that, they wouldn't take any Japanese prisoners.
So we had a hard time prevailing on Marines to bring in prisoners for intelligence service.
That's true.
That was at Guadalcanal?
That was at Guadalcanal.
I lost a lot of friends there.
You were speaking about race a minute.
Cut it off now.
Tell me, when was this written?
Do you remember?
1941, I imagine.
Where were you when it was written?
Camp Elliot under General Vogel.
Okay, 1941.
And it hired me to hang it tight in the eye.
They knew I did that.
And who did you write it to?
I wrote that to the Chief of Naval Operations.
You've got the reply back.
Okay, the reply's on the other side then.
Said we wasn't sacrosanct.
That means we had to, you know, fall in line.
So what they did, they organized a lot of battalions and set them in the back areas.
Mm-hmm, mm-hmm.
But see, that's where your lawyer comes in and your civilian comes in in your service.
He wouldn't dare ask a regular officer to do that.
Of course, I never was treated as a reserve officer because I'd been a regular officer.
You understand?
So what has happened?
You get Marcia Diane coming to this country and telling us you've got too many blacks in the service because they're mentally not mentally qualified.
What do you think about that?
I'm with him 100%.
We've had some good black Marines.
And I was sitting, they asked me... You can put this on tape.
Put it on tape.
I just turned it on right now.
I was asked by a board at Camp Pendleton after the war what I felt about black personnel.
And I said this, if we can train them properly...
and they can hit the beach and bury the breast of the battle and die along with us, I'm for them 100%.
But I don't believe in giving them anything on account of their color.
Cut it.
Cut this.
You can edit any of this stuff off when I give you the transcript.
All right.
So let's just keep it on.
Okay.
You getting tired?
No.
All right.
Let me see.
Brutality of the Japs.
I showed you that.
And how, what the Americans, what did your friends and colleagues think?
What did they think about having these prisoner of wars?
And what did they think about, I mean, how did they treat them?
The troops were never contacted.
The only people contacted were the Marine guards, the Marines.
How did the guards treat the prisoners?
They treated them fairly.
There was always an interpreter or a Marine who could speak Japanese with them.
They didn't try to abuse anybody.
The only abuse among Japanese was among themselves.
You mean they abused each other?
Yes.
In what way?
Well, they'd fight.
They'd fight with each other?
Sure, every now and then, but very seldom, very seldom.
We had no trouble.
We had no problem.
And they got 1,200 calories a day?
Those who worked got over that, 1,400 calories.
Those who didn't work got less than 1,100 calories.
There were very few of them that didn't work.
The only ones that didn't work was that stockade out there with those officers.
Why didn't they work?
Because I was mad because I had to finish a guard out there.
Why didn't they want to work?
Well, because they didn't have to.
They were officers.
And we couldn't pay the prisoners like we were supposed to because there were too many of them.
There wasn't a lot of them.
Before prisoners were 3,000.
Now you had 30,000 or more.
That's when it swelled when we took the garrison from Rota.
Those people had been over there eating frogs and lizards and rats and everything else.
We brought them over to Ireland, and we cleaned them all up, kept them there 15 to 20 days, and then sent them back to Japan.
Gave them medical?
You mean sent them back to Japan after the war?
Yeah.
Gave them medical?
Yeah.
And was the next job...
And what was the next job?
I'm trying to tell you.
You wanted to see some of the Japanese.
Has we got them in?
Yeah.
Were they real skinny and beat up?
Hell no.
I got a joke to tell on myself, too.
Okay, tell me.
On top of the...
Uh...
Well, I had headquarters call it Frog Roost.
Pacific cemeteries, you don't see that.
And up on, overlooking the Ganya Harbor.
Mm-hmm.
And I lived there with a fellow named Jim Lane, who was personnel down in the island command.
And it was just a tent up on coconut logs with a floor in it.
And the Navy stole the icebox and gave it to me for a favor.
So in cleaning out
during the assault phase, there were a lot of Japs tunneled up in these places and they thought they'd kill them all with the flamethrowers.
But there were two of them still living.
And I lived on top of them there for over eight months.
And you didn't know they were living down there?
I didn't know they were living under me.
And we had a little old monkey shower there.
We've got some pipe and we've got a little water and we had a shower and we built a little bib on the front of our tent
And that's where we'd take a shower.
So he was living off this water we'd take a shower with.
So they liked to hurrah the hell out of me about that because we found him down on... And one day I hung up my utilities and I missed him.
Well, I thought maybe the wind blew him away.
But the Jap got him and he was down there on a dump at the officer's mess prowling around with his marine clothes on.
And I never liked to live that down either, but they had my name in them.
Oh, really?
Son of a bitch.
He stole your clothes and went down to the garbage dump?
That's right.
My name was in the back of them, right back in here.
Was he wearing colonel patches?
Was he wearing colonel insignias?
Yeah, no, no, he wasn't wearing that.
So they teased you about that, I bet.
Oh, God, yes.
Good day.
We read the combat citation.
I just wanted to show you a few pictures.
Yellow leader.
Promotions.
Brutality of the Japs.
That's the song I got when I was in second year of university and I composed that.
We circulated that around.
See, you can have that.
That's when I was first lieutenant on 21st Company.
See, I'm looking for... That picture, that's some of the Japanese prisoners.
You see that woman in that room?
This little one right here?
Yeah.
Where was this?
Mark?
Mark on it.
Why was she in there?
Damn, she was on a troop boat.
They said she's only true to one.
She's true to... She only serves one Jap and that she's true to him.
That's what they said.
and give a damn.
Well, these prisoners are really well-dressed.
They look really healthy.
You don't want to see these B-29 pictures because I had to do that only.
They were all my friends out there.
A lot of Aggies out there.
Did you have a lot of Aggies on Guam?
Oh, yeah, I showed you.
Yeah, you showed me them.
I gave you one.
You got all those damn people?
You got it?
to Admiral Nimitz?
Did I?
Sure did.
I had a personal letter from him.
Really?
Will you tell me about it?
When he dropped back to Pearl, he had me come up and thank him.

He thanked me personally, but he told me then that the Code of Military Justice wasn't going to work, that the old code we had, rules for the government of the Navy, did work all through the years, what we call rocks and shoals.
And he said the brig was going to be filled up with people.
Now, I'm licensed to practice for the Court of Military Appeals over there.
See it over there?
But that's the most useless damn thing in the world because you can't have office hours without a damn lawyer being there.
Now, I'm a lawyer myself.
Why I have to stand there and worry about a bachelor who needs five days of bread and water with a full ration on the third day when that's all he could do and get it.
You understand what you can't do that, but I'm a lawyer.
So if the Admiral Nimitz is right, the brig's awful.
What have you had?
Look how many desertions you've had in all the services.
How many BCDs?
How many of this, that, and the other?
When you start with that discipline in the squad, the corporals say to you, all right, Anderson, you don't go ashore this weekend.
You leave your liberty card in the rack.
And old Anderson goes to think, what did I do?
What did I do?
And he knows what he did.
And you don't have any problem with Anderson.
Then another guy comes up and he does something, and he gives him some EPD, vector police duty to the sergeant there, or the corporal.
That straightens him out.
That stops him there.
Or if he goes up to the platoon commander, he'll give him something that's out on his record.
And he'll discipline then.
They were founded on that through the years aboard ship every place, see?
And then when it went up to the company commander, he'd shake you around.

And then if you had a court martial when it went up to the battalion commander, he might find some extenuating circumstances and he'll cut your sentence down and it gets up to the division, he'd cut it down.
And when it finally gets to the JAG office,
This cut down, that's the court of justice we've been operating through the years, not having a goddamn lawyer sitting there.
I had to go out and be a witness out at the Army or at Guam.
I thought I was in the courthouse down in Houston, all the damn lawyers.
I said, you son of a bitch, why haven't you got a rifle or something?
Why aren't you out fighting?
The war is not over yet.
Oh, I'm a legal officer, legal.
Well, what did you think of Nimitz?
He was a great admiral.
Great man.
Did you ever meet Bull Halsey?
Yes, I met Bull Halsey.
And what did you think of him?
He was a great fighting man, too.
Forward man.
He wasn't as reserved as Admiral Nimitz was, but he was a good fighting man.
In fact, Admiral Halsey gave me the order to prosecute people in Samoa.
Anybody.
